title: 107_hr4849
content: The Act may be cited as the "Standards Development Organization Advancement Act of 2002". The Congress enacted the National Cooperative Production Amendments of 1993 to promote collaborative research and production ventures with antitrust disclosure. In 1995, the National Technology Transfer and Advancement Act recognized the importance of technical standards for the national economy. The National Technology Transfer and Advancement Act of 1995 replaced thousands of unique Government standards with technical standards developed by voluntary consensus bodies, promoting a more unified national economy. Federal agencies and the private sector using the same technical standards help avoid the cost of developing duplicative Government standards. The National Technology Transfer and Advancement Act of 1995 replaced Government standards with technical standards developed by voluntary consensus bodies to enhance quality, safety, and reduce costs. Technical standards are developed in a nonexclusionary manner by nonprofit voluntary consensus standards bodies, following principles of openness, balance, transparency, consensus, and due process. The National Technology Transfer and Advancement Act of 1995 replaced Government standards with technical standards developed by voluntary consensus bodies. These standards are developed in a nonexclusionary manner by nonprofit voluntary consensus standards bodies, following principles of openness, balance, transparency, consensus, and due process. The Act ensures that there are tens of thousands of voluntary consensus standards available for government use, with key provisions such as the opportunity to participate in standards development, balancing interests, readily available access to essential information, the requirement for substantial agreement on all material points, and the right to express a position and appeal decisions. Standards developed by government entities are generally not challengeable under antitrust laws. Private developers of technical standards used as Government standards may not have the same protection, making them vulnerable to lawsuits despite low liability risk. Standards development organizations do not benefit from any antitrust violations that may occur. If voluntary consensus standards bodies are not granted relief from antitrust laws, they may have to reduce standards development activities, leading to significant financial costs for the Government and the national economy. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The National Cooperative Research and Production Act of 1993 is amended to define 'standards development activity' and 'standards development organization' in relation to voluntary consensus standards. The National Cooperative Research and Production Act of 1993 is amended to define 'standards development activity' as excluding certain activities related to exchanging competitive information. The National Cooperative Research and Production Act of 1993 prohibits engaging in conduct that would allocate a market with a competitor, entering agreements to set or restrain prices of goods or services. SEC. 4 amends the National Cooperative Research and Production Act of 1993 to include standards development organizations in the rule of reason standard for joint ventures. SEC. 5 introduces a limitation on recovery. Section 4 of the National Cooperative Research and Production Act of 1993 is amended to include standards development organizations in the rule of reason standard for joint ventures and limits liability under antitrust laws for such organizations. The National Cooperative Research and Production Act of 1993 is amended to include standards development organizations in the rule of reason standard for joint ventures and limits liability under antitrust laws for such organizations. This applies to individuals who participate in standards development activities and are likely to benefit from them. The National Cooperative Research and Production Act of 1993 is amended to include standards development organizations in the rule of reason standard for joint ventures and limits liability under antitrust laws for such organizations. This applies to individuals who participate in standards development activities and are likely to benefit from them. SEC. 6. ATTORNEY FEES. Section 5 of the National Cooperative Research and Production Act of 1993 is amended to include standards development organizations in the rule of reason standard for joint ventures. It limits liability under antitrust laws for individuals who directly participate in standards development activities and are likely to benefit from them. SEC. 7. DISCLOSURE OF STANDARDS DEVELOPMENT ACTIVITY. Section 6 of the National Cooperative Research and Production Act of 1993 is amended to allow standards development organizations to file a written notification disclosing their information to the Attorney General and the Commission within 90 days of commencing a standards development activity. Standards development organizations can file disclosure notifications within 90 days of starting an activity to extend protections to activities not covered initially or that have significantly changed. Amendments allow for notices identifying the organization and describing the activity to be submitted. The text chunk provides amendments to subsections related to standards development organizations, allowing for their inclusion in certain activities covered by the regulations.
